thread.title: Ground News - Ring in the new year with vaccines, experts urge as COVID, flu cases rise in Cook County
thread.title_full: Ground News - Ring in the new year with vaccines, experts urge as COVID, flu cases rise in Cook County

author: Ground News
title: Ground News - Ring in the new year with vaccines, experts urge as COVID, flu cases rise in Cook County
text:
Summary by Ground News Flu cases especially are sending more people to hospitals as winter temperatures plummet, families gather for the holidays and another brutal season of respiratory illness bears down on Chicago. Cook County residents should resolve to get vaccinated against COVID-19 and influenza. Only about 12% in Cook County have gotten a dose of the latest booster, which came out in September. Share menu More
Filters 1 Articles 1 Articles All Left Center Right
Chicago Sun Times Lean Left High Factuality Ring in the new year with vaccines, experts urge as COVID, flu cases rise in Cook County Dr. Rachel Rubin, senior medical officer for the Cook County Department of Public Health, shown at an April 2022 news conference, says respiratory illnesses are on the rise in Cook County and beyond.Pat Nabong/Sun-Times Cook County residents should resolve to get vaccinated against COVID-19 and influenza — and they shouldn’t wait until the new year to do it, experts say.
